INVESTMENT SUMMARY 

Investment  in  the  ASEAN  China  Investment  Fund  II  of  up  to  $25 
million  or  25%  of  the  fund's  total  share  capital,  whichever  is  less. 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will not be the single largest 
investor in the fund. 
 
Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsectors): Finance (investment funds, small and 

medium-sized enterprise [SME] finance and leasing, finance 
sector development) 

Themes (subthemes): Regional cooperation and integration (trade 

 

FI (financial intermediary) 
C 
C 

and investments), economic growth (widening access to markets 
and economic opportunities), private sector development 
(private sector investment)  
Location impact: Regional (low) 
 
Environment:   
Involuntary Resettlement: 
Indigenous Peoples:   
 
The fund will seek to provide appreciation of capital through private 
equity  investments  in  growth-oriented  SMEs  in  Association  of 
Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  countries  and  the  People’s 
Republic  of  China  (PRC),  particularly  companies  that  can  benefit 
from  the  region's  expanding  trade  and  economic  integration.  The 
fund  is  targeting  capital  commitments  of  $250  million  and  is 
organized as a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership. The 
fund  is  managed  by  UOB  Capital  Partners  (the  fund  manager), 
which  is  assisted  by  UOB  Venture  Management  ([UOBVM],  the 
fund  advisor).  The  fund  will  have  a  term  of  8  years  from  its  final 
closing. 
 
The impact of the project will be a contribution to the regional trade 
and  investment  among  ASEAN  countries  and  between  ASEAN 
countries  and  the  PRC,  and  the  demonstration  effect  of  the  fund 
leading to improved private capital flows to the SME sector in ADB 
DMCs. 
 
The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  improved  access  to  finance 
resulting  in  increased  SME  activity  in  ADB  developing  member 
countries (DMCs). 
 
The  output  of  the  project  will  be  the  establishment  of  the  fund  as

planned 
investment  opportunities,  and  make  financially  viable  investments 
over time.

This  investment  will  be  subject  to  risks  normally  associated  with 
equity  investments  of  this  nature  such  as:  (i)  suitability  of 
investment strategy; (ii) risks from competition with other funds; (iii) 
risks  from  insufficient  management  resources;  (iv)  risk  associated 
with potential conflicts of interest; (v) risks from difficulty in exiting 
investment  positions;  (vi)  currency  risks;    (vii)  political,  economic 
and  social  risks;  (viii)  risks  associated  with  accounting  and 
disclosure  standards 
international 
standards;  and  (ix)  risks  from  changing  legal  and  regulatory 
environments.    ADB  has  considered  or  defined  the  necessary 
steps to address and mitigate these risks. 
 
ADB's  support  to  this transaction is  justified  with  a  range  of  value 
additions to the fund. First, ADB's investment will act as a catalyst 
in raising funds. As a result of the current challenging fund raising 
environment,  the  fund  manager  is  finding  it  difficult  to  raise  the 
required capital for this fund. ADB's participation will send a strong 
signal  to  the  market  and  enable  the  fund  to  reach  its  desired 
capitalization.  Second, ADB’s  new  sets  of  environment  and  social 
safeguard  policies  and  procedures  will  be  crucial  in  enriching  the 
governance  of  the  fund.  These  policies  will  enable  the  fund 
manager  to  integrate  best  practices  with  regard  to  environmental 
and  social  standards  in  the  investee  SMEs  in  the  DMCs.  Third, 
ADB  can  provide  additional  support  to  the  fund  in  understanding 
the  regional  market  dynamics  through  ADB’s  multifaceted  links  to 
various governments and institutions in the region. This will enable 
the fund manager to appropriately assess future engagements and 
arrive at an accurate and informed investment decision. 

        

 

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
equity  investment  in  the  ASEAN  China  Investment  Fund  II  of  up  to  $25  million  or  25%  of  the 
fund's total share capital, whichever is less.  
 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Economic and Sector Background 

Over  the  past  decade, 1  Asia  has  become  an  increasingly  attractive  destination  for 
2. 
investors  due  to  the  region’s  rapid  economic  growth,  comprehensive  reforms,  structural 
changes,  and  increasing  globalization.2 However,  as  a  result  of  the  recent  economic  crisis,  a 
number  of  the  export-oriented  Association  of  South  East  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)3 economies 
have  been  hit  hard,  and  their  recovery  has  been  slow.  There  is  still  considerable  uncertainty 
about the duration of the economic slowdown and the extent to which Asia will be affected.  
 
3. 
Asia has become more deeply integrated with global financial markets. As a result of the 
financial crisis, such integration has led to the tightening of Asian credit markets. In assessing 
the  current  situation,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Asian  Development  Outlook  20094 
cites that, considering its robust domestic demand, the People's Republic of China (PRC) has 
an important role in the region's recovery. The impact of this crisis to Asia can still be cushioned 
by enhancing trade flow between the PRC and the smaller economies in the region. In light of 
this scenario, the fund's strategy of investing in companies that will promote greater economic 
and trade links between ASEAN and the PRC becomes even more important.  
 
4. 
Status  of  ASEAN–PRC  economic  relations.  Regional  cooperation  and  integration 
among  its  member  and  neighboring  countries  is  one  of  the  crosscutting  strategic  themes  of 
ASEAN.  The  association  is  focused  on  promoting  regional  growth  and  economic  integration, 
including economic and policy reforms and investment incentives. ASEAN also facilitates fast-
track  trade  liberalization  within  the  ASEAN  free  trade  area.  Appendix  2  gives  key  economic 
features of ASEAN and the PRC. 
 
5. 
The  PRC  is  increasingly  becoming  a  major  economic  power  in  the  region.  It  has  twice 
the land area of ASEAN, it is roughly 2.3 times larger than ASEAN in terms of population, and 
its  gross  domestic  product  is  approximately  2.25  times  that  of  ASEAN.  Also,  the  PRC's 
economic  liberalization  and  its  membership  in  the  World  Trade  Organization  are  further 
enhancing  ASEAN–PRC  trade  and  investment  opportunities.  Trade  between  ASEAN  and  the 
PRC increased by 22 times between 1991 and 2008, with the volume reaching $193 billion in 
2008.5   
 
6. 
In 2008, the PRC became the third-largest trading partner of ASEAN, behind Japan and 
the European Union, and overtook the United States, which was fourth.4 This statistical finding 
shows the increased exposure and significance of the PRC in the ASEAN trade area. Exploiting

Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Thailand, Singapore, and Viet Nam.

 2 

the  synergies  in  trade  between  ASEAN  and  the  PRC  by  adopting  an  investment  strategy  that 
will  focus  on  companies  that  can  further  the  trade  between  the  PRC  and  ASEAN  can  be 
extremely beneficial to the overall balanced economic development of the ASEAN region.  
 
ASEAN–PRC  agreement  on  trade  has  evolved  over  the  years.  In  November  2002,  the 
7. 
framework  agreement  for  the  ASEAN–PRC  free  trade  area  was  signed  at  the  eighth  ASEAN 
summit  meeting  in  Cambodia.  The  framework  agreement  committed  ASEAN  and  the  PRC  to 
negotiate  the  liberalization  and  promotion  of  trade  in  goods  and  services  between  them.  An 
announcement on bilateral investment was released on 15 August 2009; it stated that the PRC 
commerce  minister,  Chen  Deming,  and  the  economic  ministers  from  10  ASEAN  members 
signed  the  ASEAN–China  Investment  Agreement  during  the  41st  ASEAN  Economic  Ministers 
Meeting.  The  signing  of  the  investment  agreement,  together  with  the  previously  signed  PRC–
ASEAN agreements of the trade in goods and services, completed the negotiation process of a 
PRC–ASEAN free trade area, which started on 1 January 2010. This agreement envisions "to 
promote  investment  flows  and  to  create  liberal,  facilitative,  transparent  and  competitive 
investment  regimes"  for  both  ASEAN  and  the  PRC  through  defined  mechanisms  such  as, 
among  other  things,  improving  the  transparency  of  investment  rules  conducive  to  increased 
investment flows.6 
 
B. 

Investment Identification and Description 

8. 
In  2004,  ADB  made  a  $15  million  investment  in  the  ASEAN  China  Investment  Fund 
(ACIF I).7 ADB has thus known the fund manager for over 5 years and has developed a close 
relationship with the team through this investment. There are other regional funds in existence 
that  could  also  represent  worthy  investment  targets.  However,  based  on  the  alignment  of  this 
fund  with  ADB's  regional  trade  and  integration  strategies,  and  on  the  positive  economic  and 
development  outcomes  of  ACIF  I  investment,  ADB  feels  confident  contemplating  ongoing 
support for a fund manager that ADB helped to promote before.  
 
C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

9. 
Strategy  2020  identifies  private  sector  development  as  a  key  driver  of  change,  and 
finance  sector  development  as  one  of  five  core  specializations  that  support  ADB’s  agenda.8 
Strategy 2020 focuses on three strategic priorities: inclusive economic growth, environmentally 
sustainable  development,  and  regional  integration.  In  addition,  Strategy  2020  emphasizes 
private  sector  development  as  a  means  to  achieve  sustainable  and  inclusive  growth.  The 
relationship of the fund to each of the priorities and drivers of change is summarized as follows: 

 
1. 

Strategy 2020 Priorities 

(i) 

Inclusive  economic  growth.  The  fund  provides  much-needed  growth 
capital for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in ASEAN and the 
PRC.  Such  companies  play  a  vital  role  in  generating  employment  and 
supporting inclusive economic growth.

(ii) 

Environmentally  sustainable  development.  The  fund  systematically 
screens  and  monitors  all  investee  companies  for  compliance  with  ADB, 
World  Bank,  and  International  Labor  Organization  environmental  and 
social  guidelines,  and  for  compliance  with  corporate  governance  best 
practices.  In  addition,  the  fund  introduces  investee  companies  to  such 
guidelines and standards, as well as compliance procedures. 

 
(iii)  Regional  integration.  The  fund  provides  growth  capital  to  SMEs  in 
ASEAN  and  the  PRC,  particularly  those  that  can  benefit  from  the 
continuing  expansion  of  regional  trade  and  investment  between  ASEAN 
member  states  and  the  PRC,  and  their  respective  overseas  trading 
partners. The fund enables the investee companies to list their shares on 
a regional stock exchange, thus contributing to regional integration as well 
as capital markets development. 
 

2. 

Strategy 2020 Drivers of Change  

(i) 

 
(ii) 

 
(iii) 

Private  sector  operations.  The  fund  provides  a  mechanism  to  attract 
much-needed  responsible  and  sustainable  private  investment  to  ASEAN 
and the PRC. The fund catalyzes investment on two levels: firstly, through 
direct  investment  in  private  companies,  and  secondly,  by  helping  such 
companies to tap the public capital markets, typically by means of a stock 
exchange listing. 

Gender  equity.  The  fund  is  expected  to  be  an  important  source  of  job 
creation  for  women,  particularly  in  SMEs.  The  fund  monitors  the  labor 
practices and conditions of its investee companies. Such monitoring helps 
to  detect  and  correct  instances  of  gender-based  discrimination  and/or 
harassment (both of which are major impediments to hiring and retaining 
employees,  particularly  women,  in  the  workforce),  and  ensure  that 
investee companies do not use child labor. 

Partnerships.  The  fund  provides  a  mechanism  for  ADB  to  partner  with 
like-minded  investors  from  both  the  private  and  public  sectors,  who  seek 
to promote responsible and sustainable private enterprise development in 
ASEAN and the PRC. 
 

10. 
Finally,  this  project  aligns  well  with  ADB's  prior  investment  with  the  fund  manager  to 
promote SME lending and the above-mentioned ADB sector strategies, and represents a good 
fit for ADB's involvement. 
 
D. 

Development Impact 

11. 
In  this  transaction,  ADB's  investment  in  the  fund  is  intended  in  the  long  term  to  help 
increase regional trade, economic growth, and private sector development in Asia. This set of 
linkages, as detailed in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1), can be understood 
as follows: 
 

(i) 

Impact.  The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  a  contribution  to  regional  trade  and 
investment  among  ASEAN  countries  and  between  ASEAN  countries  and  the

flows to the SME sector in ADB DMCs.

resulting  in  increased  SME  activity  in  ADB  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs).

The project will promote development in a number of ways, including (i) promoting closer 
12. 
economic  and  trade  links  between  ASEAN  and  the  PRC;  (ii)  developing  SMEs,  which  will 
benefit from such links; (iii) deepening regional capital markets; (iv) helping to promote balanced 
development  and  reduce  the  risks  associated  with  overdependence  on  a  limited  number  of 
traditional  export  markets;  (v)  transforming  investee  companies  by  helping  them  to  adopt 
financially  prudent  and  sustainable  business  practices  and  internationally  accepted  standards; 
and  (vi)  catalyzing  the  mobilization  of  long-term  capital  from  institutional  investors  from  both 
within  and  outside  the  region.  See  Appendix  8  for  Environmental  and  Social  Governance 
Improvements of ACIF I Portfolio Companies.  

III. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY  

A. 

Sponsor and Ownership 

13. 
Sponsor. The United Overseas Bank (UOB) is the fund sponsor and is the lead investor 
with a capital commitment of $30 million. UOB was incorporated in August 1935 as the United 
Chinese Bank and has grown over the last 73 years. Through a series of acquisitions, it became 
a  leading  bank  in  Singapore,  with  banking  subsidiaries  in  the  region.  Today  the  UOB  has  a 
network  of  over  500  offices  in  18  countries  and  territories  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  Western 
Europe, and North America. UOB provides a wide range of financial services through its global 
network  of  branches  and/or  offices  and  subsidiaries—personal  financial  services,  private 
banking,  trust  services,  commercial  and  corporate  banking,  investment  banking,  corporate 
finance,  capital  market  activities,  treasury  services,  asset  management,  venture  capital 
management, general insurance, and life insurance. UOB is rated among the world's top banks 
by  Moody's  Investors  Service,  receiving  ratings  as  of  31  December  2007  of  B  for  financial 
strength, Aa1 for long-term deposits, and Prime-1 for short-term deposits. As of 31 December 
2007, UOB had total assets of approximately $122 billion.  
 
14. 
In 2007, UOB further expanded its operations in Asia. It received approval to incorporate 
the United Overseas Bank (China) in the PRC, and it also completed the acquisition of a 10% 
stake in the Southern Commercial Joint Stock Bank in Viet Nam. The core strengths of UOB lie 
in its market knowledge of Asia, consumer and SME banking expertise, and proven technology, 
risk management, and corporate governance framework. 
 
15. 
Ownership.  The  fund  will  be  owned  by  its  investors  (including  ADB).  Commitments 
and/or  interests  in  the  fund  thus  far  include  $30  million  from  UOB,  a  substantial  commitment 

  

5

from  the  China  Development  Bank  (CDB),  and  up  to  $10  million  from  Proparco.9 Further  fund 
investor commitment details are provided in Para. 33. 
 
B. 

Governance Structure 

1. 

Management  

16. 
The  fund  will  be  managed  by  UOB  Capital  Partners  (the  fund  manager).  The  fund 
manager  is  wholly  owned  by  UOB  Global  Capital,  a  member  of  the  UOB,  and  Westmount 
Pacific,  an  affiliate  of  Westmount  Asset  Management,  a  registered  investment  adviser  in  the 
United States. UOB Global Capital owns 70% of the fund manager and Westmount Pacific owns 
30%.  
 
17. 
The  fund  manager  will  engage  the  UOB's  wholly  owned  venture  capital  affiliate,  UOB 
Venture Management (UOBVM) to provide specialized investment advisory services to the fund. 
UOBVM will be responsible for all investment and divestment activities of the fund. UOBVM has 
extensive private equity, venture capital, and direct business operating experience, as well as a 
demonstrated ability to operate effectively in the region's multicultural environment. Appendix 3 
provides the fund's structure and organizational relationships. 

 
2. 

Corporate Governance 

18. 
Board  of  directors.  The  fund  manager  will  be  governed  by  a  board  of  directors.  The 
initial  directors  of  the  fund  manager  will  be  Kie  Cheong  Chong,  Kian-Wee  Seah,  Robert  A. 
Berliner, David T. Goss, and Michael Landau. Appendix 4 provides the biographical data for the 
initial directors of the fund manager. 
 
19. 
Advisory board. The fund will have an advisory board, consisting of representatives of 
the fund investors with commitments of at least $20 million. The fund manager will exercise its 
discretion in inviting certain fund investors with capital commitments of less than $20 million to 
be also represented on the advisory board. The advisory board will represent the interests of the 
investors,  and  advise  and  provide  guidance  to  the  fund  manager  on  matters  related  to  fund 
operations, governance, and conflicts of interest. ADB will have a seat on the advisory board. 
 
20. 
Investment committee. The fund will establish an investment committee to review and 
make decisions on the acquisition and divestment of proposed investments. The fund manager 
will not pursue any investments or cause the fund to enter into any transaction in the event of a 
negative  recommendation  by  the  investment  committee.  The  committee  will  consist  of  one 
independent member other than the UOBVM investment professionals. To avoid any potential 
conflicts of interest, the independent member of the investment committee will have veto rights 
over investment approvals. 

 
3. 

Risk Management 

For private equity funds, risk management can be understood as the process by which 
21. 
the  fund  in  question  selects,  analyzes,  structures,  and  exits  investments,  i.e.,  the  investment 
process  and  policies  that  aim  to  identify  risks,  balance  those  risks  against  the  anticipated 
returns  of  the  investment,  and  mitigate  the  risks  to  the  extent  possible.  A  key  element  in 

                                                 
9  Proparco, set up in 1977, is the French Development Finance Institution specializing in capital investments, loans, 

and guarantees. 

 

 6 

achieving  this  fund's  investment  goals  is  the  implementation  of  a  rigorous  investment  process 
by the fund manager.  
 
22. 
Investment process. The investment process used for ACIF I has been refined over the 
past  several  years,  while  retaining  the  disciplines  that  have  proven  successful.  This  proven 
investment process will be used for this fund. The investment process can be briefly described 
as follows: (i) deal sourcing, (ii) an exploratory memo seeking approval of the management of 
UOBVM, (iii) investment opportunity due diligence, (iv) investment appraisal for the investment 
committee, and (v) fund manager's approval.  
 
23. 
Investment policies. The fund manager also has a set of policies that it uses to screen 
and structure investments. The fund will carry out fundamental research and due diligence on 
each portfolio company in order to understand its objectives, management philosophies, and the 
personalities  involved.  The  fund  manager  will  seek  to  help  its  investee  companies  monitor 
market  trends  and  product  technology,  not  only  through  its  own  resources  but  also  with  the 
assistance of entrepreneurs, consultants, and industry experts. The fund will (i) seek to invest in 
SMEs  that  are  financially  sound,  with  solid  operating  performance,  profitability,  and  asset 
quality;  (ii)  have  committed  senior  management  teams;  (iii)  have  an  attractive  growth  and 
competitive position; and (iv) have a clear path to exit. The fund's portfolio companies must be 
well positioned to take advantage of interregional trade. The fund manager will also require the 
fund's portfolio companies to fully comply with national and international anti-money-laundering 
and  know-your-client  requirements.  These  policies  represent  additional  mechanisms  of 
mitigating risk beyond the investment process.  
 

 
Business Overview and Strategy 

C. 

24. 
Overview.  The  fund  will  invest  in  privately  negotiated  equity  and  equity-related 
investments  in  growth-oriented  SMEs  operating  in  the  PRC  and  the  ASEAN  region.  The  fund 
will  actively  target  growth-oriented  medium-sized  companies  seeking  capital  to  finance 
expansion, acquisitions, joint ventures, or corporate restructuring. The fund will focus on sectors 
that are well positioned in terms of competitiveness and growth prospects and on investments 
likely to benefit from increased intra- and interregional trade. 
 
25. 
Strategy.  The  fund  will  make  investments  of  $5  million–$20  million  per  company,  and 
will tend to take a minority equity stake (i.e., less than 50% in portfolio companies), which it will 
hold for an average of 3–5 years. The fund investments will generally take the form of ordinary 
or preference shares, convertible or exchangeable bonds, or debt with warrants. The fund will 
have  board  of  directors  representation  and/or  observer  status,  and  veto  power  over  major 
aspects of the portfolio company's business via a comprehensive shareholder agreement.  
 
26. 
The targeted allocation for the fund is 50% in the ASEAN region and 50% in the PRC. 
The  targeted  suballocation  for  the  ASEAN  region  is  5%–10%  for  Cambodia  and  the  Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), 25% for Viet Nam, 15%–20% for Thailand, 20%–30% 
for  Indonesia,  15%–20%  for  the  Philippines,  and  10%  for  Singapore. 10  The  targeted 
suballocation in the PRC is 20%–35% for the western region (Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Inner 

                                                 
10 All investments in Singapore will primarily be “flow through” investments (i.e., investments booked in Singapore for 

which the ultimate beneficiary country is elsewhere in the region, either in ASEAN or the PRC).   

 

  

 

Mongolia,  Ningxia,  Qinghai,  Shaanxi,  Sichuan,  Xizang  Autonomous  Region, 11 and  Xinjiang, 
Yunan,),  10%–20%  for  the  central  region  (Anhui,  Henan,  Hubei,  Hunan,  Jiangxi,  and  Shanxi), 
5%–15%  for  the  northeastern  region  (Heilongjiang,  Jilin  and  Liaoning,)  and  40%–50%  for  the 
east coast region. 
 
27. 
The  fund  will  not  invest  in  any  single  portfolio  company  that  is  more  than  15%  of  the 
fund's aggregate capital commitments. The focus industry sectors for this fund will be similar to 
ACIF  I,  which  are  energy,  consumer  services,  consumer  goods,  industrials,  health  care, 
materials, environment, and technology.

Value  addition.  The  fund  manager  will  provide  portfolio  companies  with  access  to 
31. 
management know-how, new markets, and new technology in addition to financing. Consistent

32. 
Exit. The fund aims to exit investments over an average period of 3–5 years. UOBVM's 
experience  in  Asian  private  equity  since  1992  has  demonstrated  its  expertise  in  exiting 
investments via a variety of routes, including (i) an IPO on one of the region’s stock exchanges, 
(ii)  an  IPO  on  a  stock  exchange  outside  the  region  (e.g.,  the  NASDAQ12),  (iii)  a  trade  sale, 
(iv) exercise  of  contractual  put  obligations  negotiated  at  the  time  of  investment,  and  (v)  share 
swaps  for  listed  shares  and/or  other  tradable  assets.  UOBVM  has  achieved  approximately  45 
exits utilizing all of the above routes since 1992 and will employ the same means to exit the fund 
portfolio company investments.  
 
D. 

Investment Cost and Financing Plan 

33. 
The fund manager completed the first closing of $46 million in December 2009. The first 
close included the following investors: UOB ($30 million), Proparco ($10 million), Infrastructure 
Development Finance Company ($5 million, will consider up to $15 million by final close), and 
the fund manager employees ($1million). The CDB has signed a letter of intent to invest up to 
$50 million in this fund, and this is subject to the establishment of the China Development Bank 
Capital  Corporation  (CDB's  asset  management  arm)  and  its  investment  decision  procedures. 
ADB is considering a $25 million commitment for the second close in the second quarter 2010. 
For  the  third  close  prior  to  the  end  of  2010,  the  fund  will  target  other  international  financial 
institutions,  fund  of  funds,  and  other  commercial  investors.  The  fund  expects  to  target  a 
capitalization by final closing of approximately $200 million–$250 million.  
 
E. 

Financial Performance 

34. 
Since commencing operations in 2004, ACIF I has invested in 15 portfolio companies, 6 
of  which  it  has  fully  exited.  Of  the  15  portfolio  companies,  7  have  achieved  a  public  stock 
exchange listing. For some of the portfolio companies, the ACIF I management team was able 
to  call  on  other  UOB  entities  to  provide  assistance  with  underwriting  or  other  aspects  of  the 
public listing and/or IPO process (Appendix 5 provides the ACIF I investment track record). As 
of 30 September 2009, the total cost of investments for ACIF I was $55.1 million, and the total 
realized value was $98.3 million. As of 30 September 2009, the money multiple for ACIF I was 
2.38  (including  unrealized  investments),  and  the  money  multiple  for  realized  investments  was 
3.26. As of 30 June 2009, the net internal rate of return for ACIF I was 42.07%.

35. 
The  fund’s  objective  is  to  acquire  ordinary  or  preference  shares,  convertible  or

IV. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

ADB Intervention and Transaction Structure 

36. 
ADB  proposes  to  make  an  equity  investment  of  up  to  $25  million  in  the  fund,  not  to 
exceed 25% of the fund's total commitments, whichever is less, and not resulting in ADB being 
the largest investor in the fund. ADB's equity contribution to the fund will be used exclusively for 
investments in ADB's DMCs. The fund will have an 8-year life with an option to extend fund life 
by two 1-year extensions subject to approval of the advisory board. The management fee for the 
fund  will  be  2.25%  of  the  committed  capital  (in  the  event  the  committed  capital  for  the  fund 
exceeds  $120  million  by  the  final  close,  the  management  fee  will  be  reduced  to  2.00%  of 
committed  capital  for  the  fund)  during  the  commitment  period  and  will  be  equal  to  2.00%  of 
investment  amounts  thereafter.  After  returning  all  the  investment  amounts  and  an  8%  per 
annum  preferred  return  to  fund  investors,  the  fund  manager  will  receive  25%  of  the  preferred 
return.  In  addition,  the  fund  manager  will  be  entitled  to  a  carried  interest  of  20%  subject  to 
achievement of 8% preferred return. 
 
B. 

Justification for ADB Assistance 

37. 
 

(i) 

ADB's investment in the fund is justified due to the following value-addition aspects:  

A  catalytic  role  in  raising  funds.  Despite  the  excellent  performance  with  its 
previous fund, the manager is finding it difficult to raise the needed capital for this 
fund  due  to  the  currently  challenging  fund  raising  environment.  The  Emerging 
Market Private Equity Association (a nonprofit independent association based in 
Washington,  DC)  reports  a  decline  in  private  equity  fund  raising  of  over  50% 
year-on-year in emerging markets.13 ADB involvement will send a strong signal to 
the  market  and  enable  the  fund  to  reach  its  target  level  of  capitalization  and 
sustain its funding to SMEs to facilitate regional trade. 

Advisory needs on sustainable development measures crucial to enriching 
the  governance  of  the  fund.  ADB's  new  sets  of  environment  and  social 
safeguard  policies  and  procedures 14 could  guide  the  fund  in  screening  future 
investee companies. ADB, through its participation, will support and enhance the 
activities of the fund manager and help integrate the best practices with regard to 
environmental  and  social  standards  and  corporate  governance  in  the  investee 
SMEs in the DMCs. 

ADB's  understanding  of  the  market  and  its  relationship  with  ASEAN 
member states. ADB will make available its services to help identify and assess 
target  investees  for  the  fund  and  help  demonstrate  through  this  fund  the

Risks and Mitigation Measures 

 The main risks of the investment and their principal mitigants are outlined below: 
 
(i) 

Investment  strategy.  The investment environment has changed markedly from 
the time of the predecessor fund and the use of the same investment strategy for 
this follow-on fund may be unsuitable. In response, the fund manager has made 
several important changes to its investment strategy, specifically as regard to the 
geographic  focus.  The  first  fund  invested  heavily  in  the  PRC  and  in  a  limited 
number  of  ASEAN  countries.  The  second  fund  will  target  a  wider  basket  of 
ASEAN countries including the Mekong Subregion and the Philippines. It will also 
broaden  its  coverage  of  the  PRC  to  include  the  relatively  underdeveloped 
western, central and northeastern regions. This change of focus should improve 
the investment prospects of the fund.  

 
(ii) 

 
(iii) 

 
(iv) 

Competition  for  investments  and  deal  pipeline  risk.  There  is  a  risk  that  the 
success  of  the  predecessor  fund  could  lead  to  greater  competition  from  other 
fund  managers  following  similar  strategies  and  targeting  the  same  types  of 
investments as this fund. Competition for investments may result in overvaluation 
of target investee companies and the loss of investment opportunities available to 
the fund. Companies listed in the pipeline of prospective investees may turn out 
to be unsuitable for reasons previously unidentified. This risk is partially mitigated 
by  the  abundant  need  for  equity  investment  in  the  economies  within  the  target 
region and by the fund manager's deep relationships in the market, which should 
facilitate the sourcing and development of pipeline opportunities going forward.   

Insufficient  management  resources.  Since  the  fund  manager  oversees  other 
private  equity  funds  affiliated  with  the  sponsor,  the  availability  of  sufficient 
management  oversight  on  the  fund's  investment  activities  is  an  important 
consideration. This risk is mitigated by the pre-determined time commitment from 
each of the fund manager's key business executives. Furthermore, the advisory 
agreement and the partnership agreement designate key business executives for 
the  investment  adviser  and  general  partners  whose  continued  presence  is 
required  for  the  fund's  operation.  Their  absence  would  result  in  temporary 
suspension  of  the  fund's  investment  activities  until  it  is  remedied  by  the 
appointment  of  qualified  replacements  and  lifting  of  suspension  by  the  limited 
partners.   

Potential conflicts of interest. The fund manager oversees other private equity 
funds affiliated with the sponsor. There is, therefore, potential conflict of interest 
from  competition  among  affiliated  funds  for  the  same  investment  opportunities.  
This  risk  is  modest  as  the  timing  for  this  fund  differs  from  other  sister  funds, 
which are presently in exit phase, thereby preventing competition between funds 

  

11

for  similar  investment  opportunities.  The  risk  of  this  fund  serving  as  an  exit 
mechanism for other affiliated funds is also minimal as this fund is prohibited from 
investing in companies owned by affiliates without prior approval of the advisory 
board,  whose  members  consist  of  representatives  from  the  limited  partners.  
Conflict of interest during investment phase is further controlled by the presence 
of  one  independent  investment  committee  member  who  has  veto  power  over 
decisions of the committee and whose selection is subject to ADB's right of "no 
objection".  Finally,  all  banking  and  finance  or  advisory  services  will  be  awarded 
on an arm's length basis to ensure no exclusivity with UOB.   

 
(v) 

Exit risks. The fund may experience difficulty exiting from investments within the 
planned divestment period. Valuations in the equities market may be too low for 
the  fund  to  list  its  investment  companies  or  to  profitably  exercise  its  conversion 
option after listing. This risk is partially mitigated by the fund manager obtaining 
put options at the time of purchase, where possible, and also by the policy of the 
fund manager to identify and arrange exit mechanisms at the time of investment. 
The  fund  manager's  track  record  of  successful  exits  in  the  predecessor  fund 
should also mitigate this risk to some extent.  

 
(vi)  Currency  risks.  As  the  fund  will  be  capitalized  in  US  dollars  and  as  specific 
investments  are  funded  in  the  local  currency,  the  fund  may  be  exposed  to 
currency depreciation in the countries of investment. This risk can be minimized 
through diversification of investments across the different countries of ASEAN.   

 
(vii)  Geopolitical, macroeconomic and social risks. The fund's investments will be 
in  developing  countries that  are  exposed  to  political,  economic  and  social  risks. 
These  risks  may  impact  the  returns  and  stability  of  the  fund’s  investments. 
However,  a  diversified  portfolio  approach  is  expected  to  mitigate  particular 
scenario  risk  from  any  one  country.  Furthermore,  ADB’s  bilateral  linkages  and 
close  relationship  with  the  governments  in  the  region,  which  are  seen  to  be 
supportive of prioritizing private sector development and other poverty reduction 
measures, may help mitigate these risks.   

 
(viii)  Accounting  and  disclosure  standards.  Accounting,  financial  and  other 
reporting  standards  in  many  developing  countries  in  Southeast  Asia  are  not 
equivalent to those in the United States and certain Western European countries.  
Accordingly, less information may be available to investors. These risks may be 
mitigated  by  requiring  that  the  fund  employ  international  financial  reporting 
standards and international standards on audit in the reports it submits to ADB, 
and through legal documentation that takes into consideration and mitigates the 
aforementioned risks as appropriate. 

 
(ix) 

Legal  risk  and  regulatory  risk.  Different  DMC  governments  impose  varying 
legal  requirements  for  investment  entities  like  private  equity  funds.  Because  of 
undeveloped  or  underdeveloped  regulatory  frameworks  in  most  developing 
Southeast  Asian  countries,  many  laws  and  regulations  are  being  changed  or 
amended from time to time, which to varying degrees can negatively affect future 
investments  of  the  fund.  This  risk  is  mitigated  by  a  careful  assessment  of  the 
legal  environment  by  the  fund  manager  and  by  legal  documentation  for  fund 
investments that takes such risks into consideration. The fund manager, as part

legal due diligence.   

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

Environment and Social Safeguards 

 

The fund will comply with the 2009 ADB Safeguard Policy Statement.15 A recent review 
40. 
of  the  environmental  and  social  management  system  of  ACIF  I  found  it  to  be  compliant  with 
ADB policies in effect at that time. The fund manager will enhance the environmental and social 
management  system  prepared  by  ACIF  I  such  that  it  complies  with  the  2009  ADB  Safeguard 
Policy Statement. This will form the basis of the environmental and social management system 
to  be  adopted  by  the  fund  (Appendix  6  is  a  summary  of  the  expected  environmental,  health, 
safety, labor, and governance review guidelines for this fund). In accordance with the Safeguard 
Policy  Statement,  the  fund  will  undertake  to  comply  with  applicable  national  laws  and 
regulations  and  will  apply  the  prohibited  investment  activities  list  in  respect  of  subprojects 
financed  by  ADB's  investment.  With  no  significant  environmental  impact  expected,  ADB's 
investment  in  the  fund  is  assigned  FI  with  respect  to  environment.  With  respect  to  involuntary 
resettlement  and  indigenous  people,  ADB's  investment  in  the  fund  is  expected  to  have  no 
impact  and  is  therefore  classified  category  C.  The  fund  will  screen  future  investments  and 
exclude any investments causing involuntary land or right-of-way acquisition or adverse impacts 
on indigenous people.  
 
B. 

Implementation Arrangements 

41. 
In  keeping  with  implementation  arrangements  for  the  majority  of  ADB's  private  equity 
fund investments, monitoring of this investment will be the responsibility of private equity funds 
staff  in  the  Capital  Markets  and  Financial  Sectors  Division.  The  fund  will  provide  all  investors 
with  quarterly  unaudited  financial  reports,  an  annual  financial  audited  report,  and  an  annual 
environmental  and  social  performance  report.  ADB  will  review  these  reports  on  an  ongoing 
basis, alongside information on the portfolio's valuation and performance of individual investees. 
ADB  will  also  be  entitled  to  representation  on  the  advisory  board  (i.e.,  the  fund's  governance 
body,  separate  from  the  board  of  directors),  and  via  that  representation  will  be  involved  in 
discussions and decisions related to corporate governance, portfolio valuations, and conflicts of 
interest.  
 
C. 

Anticorruption Policy  

42. 
The  fund  was  advised  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  and 
policy  relating  to  the  Combating  of  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  (2003). 
Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will 
require  the  fund  to  institute,  maintain,  and  comply  with  internal  procedures  and  controls 
following international best-practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption or money 
laundering  activities  or  the  financing  of  terrorism,  and  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from 
engaging  in  such  activities.  The  investment  documentation  between  ADB  and  the  fund  will 
further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings.

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
The ASEAN China Investment Fund II (ACIF II) will invest in privately negotiated equity 
1.  
and equity-related investments in growth-oriented small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) 
operating  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations  (ASEAN)  region.  ACIF  II  will  actively  target  growth-oriented  medium-sized  companies 
seeking  capital  to  finance  expansion,  acquisitions,  joint  ventures,  or  corporate  restructuring.  It 
will invest in existing SMEs with existing facilities or operations in ASEAN member countries. In 
the  PRC,  ACIF  II  intends  to  invest  in  SMEs  in  the  western  region  (Gansu,  Guangxi,  Guizhou, 
Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Qinghai, Shaanxi, Sichuan, Xizang Autonomous Region,1 and Xinjiang, 
Yunnan,)  central  region  (Anhui,  Henan,  Hubei,  Hunan,  Jiangxi,  and  Shanxi),  the  northeastern 
region (Heilongjiang, Jilin, and Liaoning) and the east coast region.

3. 

Environmental, Health and Safety and Risk Management 

 

 
15.   EHSLG  screening  and  monitoring  is  an  integral  part  of  the  ACIF  risk  management 
program. In this regard, the EHSLG provides a mechanism to assist the ACIF general partner to 
invest  the  funds  entrusted  to  it  in  a  prudent  and  responsible  manner  and  achieve  enhanced 
returns,  while  guarding  against  potential  financial  and  reputation  losses  for  the  fund,  its 
management, and investors.  
 
16.   After  the  in-depth  environment  and  social  due  diligence  appraisal  by  the  investment 
team, and upon a positive recommendation made by relevant team members, the proposal will 
be  reviewed  by  the  management  committee  of  the  manager,  before  being  presented  to  the 
investment  committee  for  final  approval.  The  investment  team  will  inform  management  of  any 
environmental and social risks with the investment and the mitigating measures or plans agreed 
with the investee company.  
 
17.   Once approved by the investment committee, a proposed investment may be subject to 
additional  due  diligence,  as  well  as  additional  reference  and  business  checks.  At  this  point,  a 
recommendation is made to the general partner’s board of directors for a final decision, subject 
to completion of all necessary legal documentation. Safeguard risk mitigation plans, corrective 
action plans, and other measures, as well as requirements to submit environmental and social 
monitoring reports, will be included in the legal agreements with the investee company. 

                                                 
3  The  contents  of  a  typical  environmental  and  social  audit  include  (i)  executive  summary;  (ii)  facilities  description, 
including past  and current activities; (iii) summary of national, local, and  any  applicable environmental and social 
laws (including labor) and regulations; (iv) audit and site investigation scope and procedures (including a review of 
presence  of  outstanding  liabilities,  and  administrative  and  court  cases  arising  from  noncompliance  with 
environmental and social requirements, outstanding compensation issues, among others); (v) findings and areas of 
concern; and (vi) a corrective action plan, providing for appropriate corrective actions or measures to address any 
area of noncompliance, including costs and schedule.

Transforming Investees 

 

The transformational role of ACIF has proven particularly important for companies based 

 
18.   By working closely with investee company management on EHSLG issues, ACIF helps 
transform investees, many of  which commence  operating as small, family-owned enterprises,4 
into well-managed, responsible companies that operate under, and are governed by, applicable 
government  laws  and  regulations  and  internationally  recognized  standards  on  environment, 
health  and  safety,  and  labor. 5  This  process  assists  investee  companies  to  compete  more 
effectively in regional and/or international markets.  
 
19.  
in the PRC, and represents a key responsible investment impact of ACIF. 
 
20.   While  the  PRC  has  in  place  excellent  environmental  and  labor  laws  and  regulations, 
rapid  growth  has  put  constraints  on  human  resources  in  these  sectors,  at  times  resulting  in 
enforcement issues and lack of knowledge on how to comply with the law. By way of example, 
an  ESHLG  review  of  an  ACIF  investee  found  that  a  chemical  company  had  required  safety 
equipment  but  lacked  knowledge  on  how  to  set  up  appropriate  systems,  train  its  personnel  in 
safety procedures, and where to obtain experienced trainers. ACIF was instrumental in assisting 
the company to identify and engage the needed personnel to upgrade its safety capabilities.

international financial centers; and 
pre-IPO assistance whereby the ACIF deal team spends considerable time with 
management  of  investee  companies  in  what  is  best  described  as  an  ongoing 
training  exercise,  so  that  the  management  understands  the  importance  of  good 
corporate governance and what is required to manage a listed company. 

Monitoring and Reporting 

 
26.   Once  an  investment  is  made,  close  monitoring  by  the  investment  advisor  becomes  an 
essential  aspect  of  the  investment  process.  In  almost  all  instances,  the  investment  advisor  is 
represented on the board of the portfolio company. The monitoring is further enhanced through 
periodic  visits  and  frequent  communication  with  the  management  of  the  investee  companies. 
This  enables  the  fund’s  management  team  to  keep  abreast  of  opportunities  facing  each 
investee company.  
 
27.   After a category A or B project is approved, the fund manager will communicate with the 
investee company and confirm from time to time that it is meeting compliance obligations of all 
applicable environmental and social safeguard requirements, and ACIF  will report to ADB any 
actual or potential breach of the compliance requirements promptly after becoming aware of it. 
 
28.   Environmental  and  social  performance  will  be  evaluated  annually.  The  benchmark  for 
performance  will  be  the  ongoing  compliance  against  the  applicable  environmental  and  social 
safeguard requirements. ACIF will ensure that the investee company prepares and submits an 
annual  environmental  monitoring  report  (Supplementary  Appendix  C)  and  will  review  and 
assess the investee project's performance on environmental and social safeguards issues.  
 
29.   Based  on  the  review  of  the  annual  monitoring  reports  from  the  investee  projects,  the 
environmental  and  social  safeguard manager  will  prepare  an  annual  environmental  and  social 
performance report substantially in the form set out in Supplementary Appendix D and submit it 
to  ADB.  The  fund  manager  will  also  report  on  the  social  safeguards  screening  process  and 
include  in  the  information  on  whether  any  investments  requiring  involuntary  resettlement  and 
indigenous peoples impacts were excluded from financing.

D. 

Organization and Responsibilities, Resources, and Capacity 

30.   Organization  and  responsibilities.  The  fund  manager  will  appoint  an  environmental 
and  social  safeguard  manager  (or  other  designated  officer)  who  reports  to  the  ACIF 
management  team.  The  environment  and  social  safeguard  manager  has  oversight  for 
environmental  and  social  issues,  ensures  the  resources  are  made  available  for  environmental 
and  social  management,  and  signs  and  submits  the  annual  environmental  and  social 
performance report to ADB. She or he will ensure that ADB and other cofinanciers are notified if 
the current staffing organization changes or when staff are replaced.  
 
31.   Resources  and  capacity.  The  environmental  and  social  safeguard  manager  (or  other 
designated  officer)  should  work  with  the  ACIF  management  team  to  ensure  that  adequate 
resources have been committed to allow for the effective implementation of the environmental 
and  social  management  system  policy  and  procedures.  She  or  he  will  need  to  be  technically 
qualified  and  should  work  with  relevant  environment  and  social  framework  in  carrying  out  the 
screening and due diligence or review work. She or he should attend environmental and social 
training  related  to  compliance  and  monitoring  activities  (e.g.,  ADB  or  International  Finance 
Corporation-sponsored  training,  International  Organization  for  Standardization  training).  ACIF 
will maintain a pool of qualified environmental and social consultants who can be called upon to 
assist in conducting environmental and social reviews as appropriate.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB's)  investment  in  the  ASEAN  China  Investment  Fund  II  (ACIF  II) is  ultimately 
intended,  over  the  long  term,  to  help  increase  regional  trade,  economic  growth,  and  private  sector  development  in 
Asia. It is expected to contribute to the regional trade and investment within the countries of the Association of South 
East Asian Nations (ASEAN) region, and between ASEAN and the People's Republic of China (PRC), and promote 
private  equity  participation  in  the  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  (SME)  sector  to  facilitate  balanced  and 
sustainable  economic  development  in  ADB's  developing  member  countries  (DMCs).  The  project  is  consistent  with 
Strategy  2020,  which  identifies  private  sector  development  as  a  key  driver  of  change,  and  finance  sector 
development  as  one  of  five  core  specializations  that  support  ADB’s  agenda.a  It  is  also  consistent  with  the  three 
strategic  priorities  of  Strategy  2020:  (i)  inclusive  economic  growth,  by  providing  much-needed  growth  capital  for 
SMEs  in  ASEAN  and  the  PRC;  (ii)  environmentally  sustainable  development,  by  screening  and  monitoring  all 
investee companies for compliance with ADB, World Bank, and International Labor Organization environmental and 
social  guidelines,  and  for  compliance  with  best  practices  in  respect  of  corporate  governance;  and  (iii)  regional 
integration,  by  contributing  to  the  expansion  of  regional  trade  and  investment  between  the  ASEAN  member  states 
and the PRC, and their respective overseas trading partners. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:  General intervention         
 
1. Key issues. The project is expected to increase intra- and interregional trade and indirectly contribute to poverty 
reduction  by  creating  jobs  and  sustainable  employment  in  the  PRC  and  ASEAN  member  countries  as  well  as 
potentially lowering costs of various consumer products produced by target investee companies.    
2.  Design  features.  The  fund  will  invest  in  privately  negotiated  equity  and  equity-related  investments  in  growth-
oriented SMEs operating in the PRC and the ASEAN region. The fund will actively target growth-oriented medium-
sized companies seeking capital to finance expansion, acquisitions, joint ventures, or corporate restructuring. 

C. Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  

Not applicable. 

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Key issues. ACIF II will invest in existing SMEs with existing facilities or operations. In the PRC, the fund intends to 
invest  in  SMEs  in  the  western  region  (Gansu,  Guangxi,  Guizhou,  Inner  Mongolia,  Ningxia,  Qinghai,  Shaanxi, 
Sichuan, Xizang Autonomous Region1, and Xinjiang, Yunnan), central region (Anhui, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangxi, 
and Shanxi), the northeastern region (Heilongjiang, Jilin and Liaoning,), and the east coast region. While there are 
ethnic  minorities  in  some  of  these  regions,  existing  SMEs  to  be  financed  by  the  fund  are  typically  located  in 
developed commercial and industrial zones.  On the basis of the nature of the target investment subsectors and the 
location of the potential investments, the project has been classified C under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement on 
involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. United Overseas Bank Venture Management (UOBVM), the fund 
manager,  has  adopted  an  environment  and  social  reporting  and  corporate  governance  standard  that  includes 
principles,  policies,  and  procedures  for  screening  potential  environmental  and  social  issues  related  to  involuntary 
resettlement, indigenous peoples, health and safety, and labor prior to making an investment. Each investment will 
be reviewed for such impacts and, in the unlikely event that a potential adverse social impact is identified, the fund 
manager will require investee companies to prepare the necessary plans or remedial actions with a time frame and 
estimated cost to achieve compliance.

C.  Gender and Development 

 Yes

1.  Key  issues.  The  initial  list  of  potential  investee  companies  includes  companies  involved  in  manufacturing 
(pharmaceutical, chemical, latex gloves, and fertilizer), media animation, health care facility management, and food 
processing  (cocoa,  bamboo  shoots,  tea  and  herbal  extracts,  etc.). With  the  diverse  sectors  that  will  be  covered  by 
the  fund,  qualified  women  are  expected  to  benefit  from  the  availability  of  up  to  500  jobs  related  to  the  identified 
subsectors.  The  fund  is  also  expected  to  benefit  women  in  general  by  promoting  access  to  efficiently  managed 
health  care  facilities,  and  cheaper  food  products  produced  by  investee  companies  from  ASEAN  member  countries 
and the PRC.  
 
2.  Key  actions.  Through  the  environment  and  social  reporting  and  corporate  governance  standard,  the  fund 
monitors the labor practices and conditions of its investee companies. External health and safety and labor experts 
are  hired  by  the  fund  manager  to  conduct  on-site  assessment  to  detect  and  correct  instances  of  gender-based 
discrimination  and/or  harassment  (both  of  which  are  major  impediments  to  hiring  and  retaining  employees, 
particularly women, in the workforce), review labor and working conditions, and ensure that investee companies do 
not use child labor.
